scenarioDescription:
The GJ 682 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 682 is a star with 0.27 times the mass of the Sun, and NaN times its radius. It is located 16.33 light years away from the solar system.

GJ 682 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 682 system


GJ 682 b

GJ 682 b was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory, in 2014-06, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 682 b is 4.401 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 682 b is 1.930 that of Earth. With a mass below 5 Earth masses, a density of 3.36, and a semi-major axis of 0.08 astronomical units, GJ 682 b could, potentially, be an ocean world - a planet with no dry land.


GJ 682 c

GJ 682 c was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory, in 2014-06, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.18 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 682 c is 8.704 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 682 c is 2.890 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 682 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system GJ 682, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the Multiple Observatories.
name: GJ 682 - System With 2 Exoplanets
